acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours EC50=0.105mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (CERI Hazard Data, 1997).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (dermal route) value of 1,000mg/kg (SIDS (2002)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 335mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 264mg/kg (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)), 355mg/kg, 475mg/kg, 547mg/kg and 830mg/kg (DFGOT vol.7 (1996)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A3 by ACGIH (2001) and Group 2B by IARC (1987).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (BCF=15(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data, )), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "flammable" by ICSC (2004). Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#2651) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests, chromosome aberration tests), described in NTP DB (Access on Mar., 2006), EU-RAR No.9 (2001), SIDS (2002) and ATSDR (1998).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine and chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#2651) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on fetuses at doses causing maternal toxicity, described in DFGOT vol.7 (1996).

respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: The substance is considered to cause no skin sensitization, based on the results of respiratory sensitization studies in guinea pigs (CERI Hazard Data 97-11 (2002)). However, the test methods are not detailed enough and the available data are insufficient to determine the presence or absence of skin sensitization.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available (melting point: 91.5-92degC (ICSC, 2004), test temperature: 140degC).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (SIDS (2002)): "The substance produced mild to moderate irritation of the eye."

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (SIDS (2002)): "The substance produced slight irritation of the skin" (though exposure duration is not presented).

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as a "Skin Sensitizing Substance" by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy. Also based on four cases of sensitization reported in human epidemiological studies (CERI Hazard Data 97-11 (2002) and MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (liver, heart),
Category 2 (thyroid, kidney, blood system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, heart)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (thyroid, kidney, blood system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "A man exhibited hepatic toxicity following accidental ingestion of a solution containing 4,4'-methylenedianiline, potassium carbonate and gammabutyrolactone; elevated transaminase and bilirubinemia were detected at clinical examination performed 2 days after exposure. Though the solution contain other substances, the clinical findings were consistent with those reported by Kopelman et al., which were considered to be 4,4'-methylenedianiline-induced toxic effects," "echocardiography revealed evidence of decreased septal motion and hypofunction of the left ventricle" (ATSDR (1998)), "11 patients had jaundice," "exposure to MDA caused hepatitis" (EU-RAR No.9 (2001)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies including "hyperplasia of the bile duct," "hyperplasia of the thyroid gland" (ATSDR (1998)), "anemia, hyperplasia of the small bile duct, hypertrophy of the thyroid gland follicular epitheliocytes, nephrocalcinosis," "hepatic parenchyma was replaced by the proliferative bile duct, leading to portal cirrhosis" (EU-RAR No.9 (2001)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (liver, kidney, heart, central nervous system, visual organs)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (liver, kidney, heart, central nervous system, visual organs)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "influenza-like symptoms with fever, jaundice," "blurred vision progressed to a significant decrease in vision; hepatic toxicity was observed," "hepatic toxicity, progression of albuminuria/hematuria," "myalgia and arthralgia" (ATSDR (1998)), "hepatitis observed in 3 days," "hepatitis," "acute hepatic symptoms," "severe pain above the navel, jaundice, electrocardiographic abnormalities suggesting cardiac muscle damage" (EU-RAR No.9 (2001)), and the evidence from animal studies including "necrosis and hemorrhage of the hepatocyte/bile duct" (ATSDR (1998)), "liver and kidney damage," "exophthalmos, hunchback position, rough fur," "indifference, chromodacryorrhea, jaundice" (EU-RAR No. 9 (2001)), "atrophy of the nucleus of rod/cone/outer nuclear layer of the retina" (CERI Hazard Data 97-11 (1998)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
